summary: You managed to open a dialogue but much more could be done in terms of active listening, acknowledging the resident's nonverbal cues of frustration, and tailoring your message to address the resident's concerns more effectively. Remember, the goal is not only to convey your message but to genuinely engage with and listen to the person you're speaking toâ€”finding common ground and addressing specific concerns can significantly enhance the effectiveness of your canvassing.

strengths.title: Polite Greeting
strengths.description: Initiated contact with a greeting before making your request, which is polite and expected in such scenarios. This is a good foundation for establishing initial rapport.

strengths.title: Clear Purpose
strengths.description: You directly stated your purpose ("vote labour"), which clearly conveys your intention. It's essential to be clear about why you're there.

areas_for_improvement.title: Active Listening
areas_for_improvement.description: Improve your active listening skills to better understand and address the resident's concerns.

areas_for_improvement.title: Nonverbal Cue Recognition
areas_for_improvement.description: Work on acknowledging and responding to the resident's nonverbal cues of frustration.

areas_for_improvement.title: Message Tailoring
areas_for_improvement.description: Focus on tailoring your message to more effectively address the specific concerns of the resident.

areas_for_improvement.title: Engagement
areas_for_improvement.description: Aim to genuinely engage with the person you're speaking to, rather than just conveying your message.

areas_for_improvement.title: Finding Common Ground
areas_for_improvement.description: Work on identifying and emphasizing common ground between your position and the resident's concerns.
